citation.article-title: Isolation and characterisation of a novel sulphate-reducing bacterium of the Desulfovibrio genus.

p.s: Description of Desulfovibrio indonensis sp. nov.

Microscopy observations revealed that the cells of Ind 1 were rod-shaped, Gram-negative and occurred singly or, during certain stages of the growth, as chains containing two or more bacteria [Figures 1 and 2(a)].
Cells were 3–5 μm long and 0.5–1.2 μm wide.
The cells were motile, moving by means of a single polar flagellum [Figure 2(b)].
Sporulation was never observed.
The ranges of temperature, pH and salinity that facilitated the growth of Ind 1 were from 10°C to 37°C, 6.5 to 8.5 and 0% to 10% (w/v) NaCl, respectively.
No growth was observed below or above these limits.
The cultures were able to reduce sulphate to sulphide using lactate and pyruvate as carbon sources.
Other tested compounds were not utilised.
From the growth curve obtained following the optical density measurements at 660 nm, a specific growth rate (μmax) of 0.07/h was determined.
Lactate consumption and acetate production curves of the culture growing in lactate/sulphate medium (Figure 3) demonstrate an incomplete lactate oxidation to acetate.
The fatty acid profile of Ind 1 is shown in Table 1.
The analysis revealed large amounts of branched fatty acids which account for 53.1% of the total fatty acids with anteiso C15:0 being the predominant species (52.86%).
With the exception of C18:1ω7c (which accounted for 1.34% of the total fatty acids), only traces of monounsaturated fatty acids were detected.
The 16S rRNA sequence data analysis established that the isolated strain Ind 1 belongs to the genus Desulfovibrio.
The similarity levels between Ind 1 and some SRB strains of the Desulfovibrio genus were determined, revealing a high similarity with D. desulfuricans, D. gigas and D. vulgaris.
Recently, a second 16S rRNA sequence analysis was performed, which confirmed the DSM 16S rRNA sequence analysis and revealed a similarity level of 97% with Desulfovibrio gabonensis (Prof.
W.
A.
Hamilton, personal communication), a recently described strain [38].
Table 2 summarises the similarity values obtained for the isolated Desulfovibrio strain.
Molecular phylogeny of Desulfovibrio Ind 1

The 16S rRNA gene from Ind 1 was sequenced from positions 74 to 966 (Escherichia coli numbering [42]) and aligned with sequences from bacteria belonging to the α, β and δ subdivisions of the Proteobacteria.
Phylogenetically uninformative information was removed from the alignment manually, leaving 500 nucleotides containing 92 informative sites.
Phylogenetic trees were constructed from distances calculated using the Kimura 2-parameter model [39] using the nearest-neighbour method [40].
Outgroups were chosen from the α and β subdivisions and included Agrobacterium tumefaciens, Neisseria polysaccharia, Pseudomonas cepacia str.
G4, and Pseudomonas fluorescens.
The phylogenetic trees obtained presented a picture that was consistent with previous reports [41,42].
The two main branches of the mesophilic Gram-negative sulphate-reducing bacteria are shown in Figure 4.
The majority of Desulfovibrio species are placed within the first major branch with good support (93% bootstrap).
The second major branch contained the remaining genera of the sulphate-reducing bacteria and Myxococcus xanthus.
Support for these major branches was very strong (99% bootstrap).
Within the Desulfovibrio lineage, Desulfomonas pigra, Desulfovibrio desulfuricans ATCC 27774, Desulfovibrio vulgaris and Desulfovibrio longreachii form a clade.
This observation is consistent with those of Devereux et al. who identified five major lineages within this group [42].

The organisms representing these lineages were (i) Desulfovibrio salexigens and Desulfovibrio desulfuricans El Aghelia Z, (ii) Desulfovibrio africanus, (iii) Desulfovibrio desulfuricans ATCC 27774, Desulfomonas pigra and Desulfovibrio vulgaris, (iv) Desulfovibrio gigas and (v) Desulfovibrio baculatus and Desulfovibrio desulfuricans Norway 4.
In Figure 4 only four of these lineages are implied: the organisms representing the fifth lineage were omitted from analysis.
The Desulfovibrio gigas lineage represents a deep branch within this group [42] and has been expanded to include Desulfovibrio gabonensis DGU31080, a marine isolate [38].
Strain Ind 1 joins this group pairing with esulfovibrio gabonensis (100% bootstrap).
Both of these species are marine but with enough sequence dissimilarity to suggest that Desulfovibrio Ind 1 is a new and separate species.

s.i: Whole cell, OM and extracellular polymers protein profiles

p.s: The protein profiles obtained for the whole cells of Desulfovibrio Ind 1 and D. gabonensis are presented in the electrophoretogram shown in Figure 5.
The patterns obtained for outer membranes and extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) are not shown.
In all cases, differences between the two strains are apparent both in the number of proteins and their ratios.
The main differences found are indicated by arrows.
Cytochrome c3.

The UV/visible spectrum of cytochrome c3 [Figure 6(a)], exhibits typical absorption bands for both the oxidised (530 nm and Soret band at 419 nm) and dithionite reduced forms (α band at 551 nm, β band at 522 nm and Soret band at 418 nm) [43].
The 1H-NMR spectrum of the Ind 1 cytochrome c3 (data not shown) presents numerous common features with the spectra from other tetrahemic cytochromes [44,45].
Downfield chemical shifted heme methyl groups are observed experiencing the low spin paramagnetism of the protein.
The Ind 1 cytochrome c3 NMR spectrum is almost identical to the spectrum reported for the homologous protein from D. gigas [46].
Hydrogenase.
The UV/visible spectrum of the native, as isolated hydrogenase, shows typical Fe-S charge transfer bands in the 400 nm region with a broad shoulder centred at 440 nm [Figure 6(b)].
The isolated hydrogenase is a dimer of 92 kDa which contains subunits of molecular weights 32 and 60 kDa, as determined using SDS-PAGE.
The enzyme’s specific activity, as determined by H2 production, is 2.71U/mg protein.
The EPR spectrum of the enzyme in the native state, at high temperature (100 K), shows a rhombic-type signal with g values of 2.32, 2.24, and 2.01 [Figure 7(a)].
This EPR signal, known as the Ni-A signal, is similar to the nickel signal observed at this temperature in the D. gigas hydrogenase (g values of 2.31, 2.23 and 2.01) [47].
The Ni-A signal has been related to an oxygenated, unsteady state of the enzyme, that can be reversibly activated.

In addition to the nickel EPR detectable species, an EPR active oxidised [3Fe-4S] cluster can be observed up to 40 K (inset of Figure 7), associated with an almost isotropic EPR signal centred at a g value of 2.02.
This signal is very similar to the one reported for the [3Fe-4S] cluster of D. gigas and D. vulgaris Miyazaki [NiFe] hydrogenases [48,49].
Sulphite reductase (desulfoviridin).
The purified Desulfovibrio Ind 1 sulphite reductase exhibited a dark-green colour.
The UV/vis spectrum presented in Figure 6(c) shows absorbance peaks with maxima at 631, 580, 409 and 394 nm, these peaks being characteristic of the desulfoviridin-type sulphite reductases.
The nonhemic iron content determined colorimetrically following the TPTZ method was 18 ± 1 atoms of iron per molecule.
This value is similar to those reported previously for other dissimilatory sulphite reductases [50].
The molecular weight of the desulfoviridin in the native state (determined employing HPLC gel filtration), was found to be 218 kDa.
Oligomeric structure and subunity molecular weight determination using SDS-PAGE revealed two bands of molecular weights 54 and 47 kDa (12.5% T gels) and a third band at around 10 kDa (17.5% T gels).
Considering the molecular weight of the native protein, the presence of these three types of subunits indicates an α2β2γ2 subunit structure.
These results are in agreement with previous reports on sulphite reductases of the desulfoviridin type [51].
Ferredoxin.
The purified ferredoxin was of an orange-brown colour and the UV/vis spectrum showed a broad maximum at 430 nm and a protein peak at 280 nm [Figure 6(d)].
The extinction coefficient at 430 nm is 15.2 mM/cm.
The low absorbance observed at 260 nm demonstrates the absence of nucleic acids contamination, indicating a highly pure ferredoxin preparation.
The purity of the ferredoxin sample was confirmed by obtaining a single NH2-terminal sequence (Figure 8).
The molecular weight of the ferredoxin in the native state, determined using HPLC gel filtration, was 18.4 kDa.
The iron content for the native protein determined colorimetrically following the TPTZ method was 10.8 ± 0.5 atoms of iron per molecule.
The EPR spectrum of the as-isolated ferredoxin recorded at 10 K is silent (data not shown), indicating that the protein is diamagnetic in its native form.
After addition of a few aliquots of sodium dithionite (1 mg/mL), the orange brown colour of the ferredoxin sample bleached, as expected for the reduced form of an [Fe-S] centre.
The EPR spectrum of the reduced protein could only be observed at low temperature (4.5 K) and showed a rhombic signal, with g values of 2.08, 1.93 and 1.86.
These EPR results are characteristic for a [4Fe-4S] centre [52].
